title: AB 2687
content:
The State of California enacts the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The law also applies to individuals addicted to drugs, except those in approved treatment programs. It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04 percent or more of alcohol in the blood. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04 percent or more alcohol, it is presumed the person had that amount while driving. (e) Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is in the vehicle. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is presumed the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows that level. 
(f) Driving under the influence of any drug is unlawful.
(g) Driving under the combined influence of alcohol and drugs is also unlawful. Section 23153 of the Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or more, causing bodily injury to others. It is also illegal to neglect any duty while driving under the influence. Proof of neglecting duties does not require specific violations of the vehicle code. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, causing bodily injury to others. A chemical test within three hours after driving can be used as evidence. It is unlawful to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is present and causes bodily injury to another person. A chemical test within three hours after driving can be used as evidence. It is illegal to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to another person. This law creates new offenses and penalties without requiring reimbursement by local agencies or school districts.
